commit.message:
Declare all Extension sources unconditionally

The dynamic nature in which sources were added to the Extension object
at build time meant that the extra sources (crc32_adler.c and
checksse42.c) were not included in source distributions produced via the
"sdist" setup.py command (because the "build" command does not run as
part of "sdist"). This in turn meant that trying to install such source
distributions in Intel platforms failed because the building process
failed to find the missing files in the source distributions.

This problem was introduced in 21a464c but went unnoticed until now
because we have been producing source distributions locally using the
exact same environment for years, before that particular change was
introduced (and therefore our local copy of the MANIFEST already
contained the two files as part of the distribution). Now that we are
moving towards producing all distribution files in GitHub via its
Actions functionality we stumbled upon this particular issue.

Fixing this problem involves adding back the two source files to be part
of the Extension unconditionally, and instead add the proper macro
checks to include the file's contents conditionally depending on the
target platform.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree b38871baddf2f45457bb7e6f2248b250b56044cf
parent 46ea36dcad0a477aa69b3eb9810cdffe4a4045be
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1593403439 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1593403937 +0800

Declare all Extension sources unconditionally

The dynamic nature in which sources were added to the Extension object
at build time meant that the extra sources (crc32_adler.c and
checksse42.c) were not included in source distributions produced via the
"sdist" setup.py command (because the "build" command does not run as
part of "sdist"). This in turn meant that trying to install such source
distributions in Intel platforms failed because the building process
failed to find the missing files in the source distributions.

This problem was introduced in 21a464c but went unnoticed until now
because we have been producing source distributions locally using the
exact same environment for years, before that particular change was
introduced (and therefore our local copy of the MANIFEST already
contained the two files as part of the distribution). Now that we are
moving towards producing all distribution files in GitHub via its
Actions functionality we stumbled upon this particular issue.

Fixing this problem involves adding back the two source files to be part
of the Extension unconditionally, and instead add the proper macro
checks to include the file's contents conditionally depending on the
target platform.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message: unbuffered
no quote huh
tests script
tests
add github actions

crc32c v2.0

This new version changes the import logic to automatically fallback to
using the software implementation when no hardware support can be found
(and hence the package doesn't fail to import).

Since this is a change in behavior, a new major version is being
produced. Users shouldn't have many problems though.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

crc32c v2.0

This new version changes the import logic to automatically fallback to
using the software implementation when no hardware support can be found
(and hence the package doesn't fail to import).

Since this is a change in behavior, a new major version is being
produced. Users shouldn't have many problems though.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Changing high-level package descriptions

Because we now support not only Intel's CRC32C instruction, but also a
software implementation of the crc32c checksum algorith, the description
of the package should not define the package as "exposing the Intel
instructions", but more as a package implementing crc32c, using Intel
when possible.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 1892962a0421ea26b16d7305b939357218b0a8d5
parent 77f3688c1f971308abe858963b50ee5c06ff91ed
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1575259052 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1575259440 +0800

Changing high-level package descriptions

Because we now support not only Intel's CRC32C instruction, but also a
software implementation of the crc32c checksum algorith, the description
of the package should not define the package as "exposing the Intel
instructions", but more as a package implementing crc32c, using Intel
when possible.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Module-level flag indicating implementation nature

Now that the module successfully imports by default regardless of
hardware support, we need to let users know if the implementation they
are using is hardware- or software-based in case they need to make
decisions based on performance.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 0d32c690f29effa69cb22c82cddb7ce2acb1adb5
parent 27f635d3c36942b226287d36a5387e0cbc0e9711
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574629514 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574630110 +0800

Module-level flag indicating implementation nature

Now that the module successfully imports by default regardless of
hardware support, we need to let users know if the implementation they
are using is hardware- or software-based in case they need to make
decisions based on performance.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
New default behavior when hw support is missing

The previous behavior raised an ImportError when no hardware support was
found by default, unless the user opted into using the software support.
With time it became clear that this was not the optimal solution, as
most people simply want to use the algorithm, regardless of software
support.

With this change the default behavior is to fallback into using the
software implementation of the crc32c algorithm instead of failing.
Users can still opt out of this by specified CRC32C_SW_MODE=none, which
will give them the old behavior.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 8455d251a76a3d2424aa88683f4ef8e4cc581ce9
parent 004416e68c2a119337483f70394609ad9c94b13d
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574629486 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574629486 +0800

New default behavior when hw support is missing

The previous behavior raised an ImportError when no hardware support was
found by default, unless the user opted into using the software support.
With time it became clear that this was not the optimal solution, as
most people simply want to use the algorithm, regardless of software
support.

With this change the default behavior is to fallback into using the
software implementation of the crc32c algorithm instead of failing.
Users can still opt out of this by specified CRC32C_SW_MODE=none, which
will give them the old behavior.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
New "none" software mode

With the future change of the default behavior in case of missing
hardware support (i.e., by default it will always be offered), a new
software mode will allow users to opt in into the old behavior by
explicitly asking they do not want a software implementation.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree bdee18ea595c44d5cf3449ad6fb0b51c67431043
parent 36f9d53d67eaab6306e35420537cdd37f033be95
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574626717 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574626948 +0800

New "none" software mode

With the future change of the default behavior in case of missing
hardware support (i.e., by default it will always be offered), a new
software mode will allow users to opt in into the old behavior by
explicitly asking they do not want a software implementation.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Removing "1" as a valid CRC32C_SW_MODE value

This was known to be deprecated in the documentation, and we are
removing it here in preparation for the addition of new modes.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574626533 +0800

Removing "1" as a valid CRC32C_SW_MODE value

This was known to be deprecated in the documentation, and we are
removing it here in preparation for the addition of new modes.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
Using enumeration to identify software modes

This makes the code more readable than before, where we used a different
flag for each different mode. Since we are planning to use the software
implementation by default in the future, new values in the enumeration
will appear to support (or improve) different scenarios.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree a6056957eba9e2e1626fbebd724674a8fbfe6a2a
parent 5215c66d8c8ecf49e859e6f679ca63cb9174bf19
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574626367 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1574626367 +0800

Using enumeration to identify software modes

This makes the code more readable than before, where we used a different
flag for each different mode. Since we are planning to use the software
implementation by default in the future, new values in the enumeration
will appear to support (or improve) different scenarios.

commit.message:
Adding platform= option to build_ext command

This new option should allow users to build the module in a
cross-compilation scenario, where the host's platform is not the
target's.

This is a different way of implementing the idea shown in #10.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

verification.payload:
tree 3658bbbe388f0b448d6cf36bbedf46ab3e1f9454
parent e0d84564bae3883ab12ae565d125b9e1f269d54a
author Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1558327175 +0800
committer Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org> 1558327237 +0800

Adding platform= option to build_ext command

This new option should allow users to build the module in a
cross-compilation scenario, where the host's platform is not the
target's.

This is a different way of implementing the idea shown in #10.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>

commit.message:
crc32c 1.6

This new version brings build fixes for non-intel platforms (patch by
Jeremy Lainé), new supported values for the CRC32C_SW_MODE environment
variable, and build support for the Intel compiler.

Signed-off-by: Rodrigo Tobar <rtobar@icrar.org>
